channel.title: How to make Throne of Lies a better social deduction game
channel.description:
When I play social deduction games im looking to do 2 thing's
A: Lie
B: Find liers
Now in the game the BD is doing B and the Unseen/NK is usually doing A. This is great and all but the best rounds involve doing both.
Remember ToS? One of the best roles in that game is the unrevealed mayor. Why? Because your a town that can legitimately fake claim and has reason to do so. You can claim your invest ad that X person should wisper claim to you. Or that your jailor and everyone should claim to you now to save time. Someone calls you out on it and you reveal.
Now simply having an easily confirmable class is not good enough. You also need to give the evils a reason to act differently in the face of a lie.
There is 1 example of this I can think of: let's say your Good king and the sheriff wants you to out an Unseen for him. You could wisper that unseen something like "Yo. Evil king here! Who is the other Unseen?" And then out them all when/if he tells you.
The key here is that the evils didn't know all of their Ally's and can be tricked because of it.
Now while there are roles like the witch in ToS that isn't enough. What you need is an Unseen/Cult class that doesn't meet with them that can get information on them and others.
Every heard of the corrupt in FoL? They had a source that was NS, could get classes and visits and was critical to winning. That's the kind of class I'm talking about. If you act as a class like that then you get more information out of evils.
Now I'm not suggesting we add the corrupt but what I am saying is that we need a scum Neutral investigative that can be faked by BD to gain the unseen/cults trust.
There is another kind of uncertainty however. A class that can change your objective without telling you would open up so meny door's.
Example: (this probably isn't balanced at all)
The Evangelical - BD special
Night ability: Make a player's wincon change to yours. Does not notify them or change their class. Will fail if used on an unconvertible neutral. (1 use)
The Corrector - Unseen special
Night ability: The next Conversion will not notify the target and will not change their class or add the the maximum Unseen (1 use)
You can them your class and what you just did (even if you did nothing). The example I gave would not work on its own but something similar might.

item.title: How to make Throne of Lies a better social deduction game
item.dc:creator: Vandalay
item.description:
NuclearBurrito:

Personally I consider this to be a good thing. I love clusterfucks and you should remember that even if BD can lie doesn’tean they always will lie. It would mostly be done with classes that can prove themselves like Prince, Psychic or Noble and classes that can use that info on they’re own such as King and Hunter.

Right but the thing to know is, the evils will almost always win in a clusterfuck. The one thing unseen has going for them, is that they can’t be fooled with regards to their most important allies.

Being able to prove yourself is all well and good, but many of your allies aren’t going to wait around for that, a knight, hunter or BD siding alc etc… isn’t going to wait for solid undeniable proof that the fool acting character is a fool, all they know is he seems clearly to be acting outside of the interests of the BD, and that the only reason there’s been a delay in putting him up to the stand is the fear of a fool.

Not to mention when people actually do what everyone in that position of lying as BD claims they should… IE investigate before lynching, it’s even worse… So you’ll often wind up with scenerios like.

Prince is acting like a fool. that night hunter wolfs him, observer window peaks him. knight attacks him. So next day he comes out and explains it, now you’ve basically wasted one of the 2 use abilities, if you are lucky you’ve only wasted a physicians heal if you have one available. Killed a knight, and still had to come out anyway. Meanwhile the unseen/cult got to act pretty freely that night. Converted and/or killed… while all the BD was busy focusing on their own.

Whether you find it fun or not… surely you have to acknowledge that 99/100 times those things don’t go well.

item.title: How to make Throne of Lies a better social deduction game
item.dc:creator: NuclearBurrito
item.description:
Neutral investigatives (not witchsig) can back up evils and provide them with alibis. This is important because if your BD then you can BS something to see how they act.

Hidden wincon changes means that you can convince someone things about THEMSELVES that are not true (if there is uncertainty about your win con then it is possible to convince you to act in ways that hurt your team without them truly knowing they are. The point is that giving the evils uncertainty about thier Ally’s means that the BD has reason to lie to them. Having uncertainty about your own wincon give BD a reason to lie to BD and unseen a reason to lie to Unseen.

Remember what I said is the point of social Deduction?

Lying and finding lyiers. If everyone has a reason to lie then everyone is doing both making the game more fun.
